raw_text:
Chancellor rallies Labour voters
 
 Gordon Brown has issued a rallying cry to supporters, warning the "stakes are too high" to stay at home or protest vote in the next general election.
 
 The chancellor said the poll - expected to fall on 5 May - would give a "clear and fundamental" choice between Labour investment and Tory cuts. He told his party's spring conference the Tories must not be allowed to win. The Conservatives and Lib Dems insisted that voters faced higher taxes and means-testing under Labour.
 
 To a packed audience at Gateshead's Sage Centre, Mr Brown accused shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin of plotting cuts that were the equivalent of sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in the country. Laying into the Conservative's record in government he said: "I give you this promise - with Labour, Britain will never return to the mistakes of ERM and 10% inflation, 15% interest rates, £3bn in lost reserves, 250,000 repossessed, one million in negative equity and three million unemployed. "Never again Tory boom and bust.
 
 "This will be the central dividing line at the election, between a Conservative Party taking Britain back and planning deep cuts of £35bn in our services, and a Labour government taking Britain forward, which on a platform of stability will reform and renew our hospitals, schools and public services and, I am proud to say, spend by 2008 £60bn more." Turning to the economy, the chancellor promised to continue economic stability and growth in a third term in power.
 
 He also pledged to continue the fight against child and pensioner poverty. And he promised help to get young people on the property ladder. "My message to the thousands of young couples waiting to obtain their first home is that housing is rightly now at the centre of our coming manifesto," he said. "And the next Labour government will match our low mortgage rates with a new first-time buyers' initiative." In the speech, which prompted a standing ovation, he also promised to end teenage unemployment within the next five years.
 
 He also highlighted plans for 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries, a national minimum wage for 16 and 17-year-olds, the creation of a network of children's centres and flexibility in maternity leave. Responding to the speech, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, George Osborne, said: "This was more talk from Gordon Brown. "We've heard it all before. Instead of talking about the future he kept on talking about the past. "He completely failed to say which taxes he would put up to fill the black hole in his spending plans. "There will be a simple choice at the election - value for money and lower taxes with the Conservatives, or more waste and higher taxes under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown."
 
 Liberal Democrat shadow chancellor Vince Cable warned the picture was not as rosy as Mr Brown would like to portray it. "For all his trumpeting of Labour's management of the economy, Gordon Brown's record is very mixed," he said. "Gordon Brown has created a system of massive centralisation and bureaucracy, a system which subjects millions of people to means testing, and a system of taxation which is extremely complex. "For all his positive words, Gordon Brown is faced with economic problems looming on the horizon, not least the unprecedented levels of personal debt facing the nation." Also in Gateshead, the prime minister took questions sent in by e-mail, text message and telephone as part of Labour's attempt to engage the public in their campaign. Mr Blair told the audience he believed the Iraq war would have made Britain a safer place if its emerging democracy succeeded and that he wanted to bring troops home as soon as possible, but not before the job was done. He also said he wanted to carry on as PM "because I still think that there are big changes our country needs".
llama3.2:1b: Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced his support for Labour in the next general election, warning of the "stakes are too high" for voters to stay at home or protest vote. He accused the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats of plotting cuts under Labour, particularly affecting teachers, GPs, nurses, and social services. Brown promised a £60bn increase in spending on hospitals, schools, and public services, and vowed to continue economic stability and growth in a third term in power. He also highlighted plans for debt relief in poor countries, lower taxes with the Conservatives, and an end to teenage unemployment within five years.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Brown rallies Labour voters, warning of Tory cuts and accusing the Conservatives of plotting to sack every teacher, GP, and nurse. He promises a Labour government will spend £60bn more by 2008, reform public services, end teenage unemployment within five years, and provide debt relief for poorest countries.
gemma2:2b: Gordon Brown urged Labour voters to vote in the upcoming general election and warned about the stakes of a potential Conservative victory. He highlighted contrasting policies, with Labour promising investment in public services while the Conservatives advocated for cuts.  He emphasized past achievements, like economic stability and poverty reduction, but also outlined future plans, including housing assistance and ending teenage unemployment. Critics countered Brown's proposals with arguments regarding his spending plan and record of bureaucracy and complexity.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Gordon Brown warned voters about potential cuts during his speech at Labour's spring conference, citing the Conservatives' promises of deeper tax rises and means-testing as a way to justify their election plans. He called for support from the public in a "central dividing line" between a Conservative government and a Labour Party that would prioritize services and stability. The prime minister also addressed economic issues such as child and pensioner poverty, home ownership, and job creation.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Chancellor Gordon Brown rallies Labour voters by emphasizing a "clear choice" between investment and Tory cuts in the next general election, promising reforms and increased spending in services but criticizing shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin's proposed deep cuts. He pledges to continue economic stability, fight poverty, and create opportunities for young people on housing benefits. Brown faces opposition from Conservatives and Lib Dems over higher taxes and means-testing, with warnings about past mistakes like 1970s policies that led to unemployment, debt, and economic instability under the Tories.
qwen2.5:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown rallied Labour voters by warning them against staying at home or protesting in the upcoming general election, highlighting a stark choice between Labour's investment and Tory cuts. Brown accused shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin of proposing cuts equivalent to laying off all teachers, GPs, and nurses. He emphasized Labour’s promise for stability and reforms, including £60bn more spending by 2008, stability in the economy, and tackling poverty and youth unemployment. In contrast, George Osborne criticized Brown's speech as nostalgic and lacking concrete tax plans. Vince Cable of the Liberal Democrats warned that Brown's economic record was mixed with issues like centralization, means testing, and complex taxation. At his conference, Prime Minister Tony Blair addressed questions from the public, expressing a desire to bring troops home but not before achieving success in Iraq.
opencoder:1.5b: The summary of the text preserves key ideas like the chancellor's rallying cry and promises for future development in the economy, taxes, and public services. The text also highlights differences in economic practices between Gordon Brown and Labour, which might influence public opinion on future policy. However, it does not provide an explanation or a detailed reasoning process as requested.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

Gordon Brown has issued a rallying cry to supporters, warning the "stakes are too high" to stay at home or protest vote in the next general election. The chancellor said the Tories would not be allowed to win and warned that Labour's record was very mixed. To a packed audience at Gateshead's Sage Centre, Mr Brown accused shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin of plotting cuts that were the equivalent of sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in the country. He promised to continue economic stability and growth in a third term in power. He also pledged to end child and pensioner poverty within the next five years and to match our low mortgage rates with a new first-time buyers' initiative. In the speech, which prompted a standing ovation, he also highlighted plans for 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries, a national minimum wage for 16 and 17-year-olds, the creation of a network of children's centres and flexibility in maternity leave.

The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text without explaining or interpreting them.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Gordon Brown's rally against Labour voters in the next election. Let me read through it carefully.

First, I'll start by understanding what each section is saying. The main points seem to be about Mr. Brown issuing a united call, his criticism of the Conservatives' taxes and policies, his economic promises, and his political stance during the campaign.

The first paragraph talks about the voters rallying calling for an election where Labour can take control. He's warning against staying at home or voting against the election. 

Next, he mentions that the poll is expected on May 5th and will give a choice between Labour investment and Tory cuts. He warns the Tories must not win, pointing out higher taxes and means-testing under Labour.

Then, Mr. Brown speaks to the Conservative's shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin about his record. He says Labour can't afford to cut because of their record with ERM, 10% inflation, £3bn in reserves, etc. So he compares it to Tory's "boom and bust" cycle.

He mentions that this will be the election's dividing line: Conservative reversion to previous mistakes versus Labour's forward plan.

He also talks about economic stability, fighting poverty, ending unemployment, and his campaign efforts at gateshead with e-mails, text messages, and telephones. He even mentioned helping Blair with moving troops for Iraq if needed.

I need to condense this into a concise summary without explanations or formatting. So I'll list the key points: rallying call from Brown, election choice between Conservative and Labour, his critique of Tory's economic policies, Labour's vision for stability and reforms, e-mails during the campaign, Blair's support for Iraq efforts, and the role of the UK government in reforming healthcare.

I should make sure it's plain text only, without any extra explanations or markdown. Let me piece this together now.
</think>

The summary highlights Gordon Brown's united call for an election where Labour can secure control. The poll will offer a choice between Labour investments and Tory cuts, warning that the Tories must avoid being chosen under their current system. Mr. Brown criticizes the Conservative government's record with large taxes and bureaucratic inefficiencies, comparing it to the Tory economy's oscillating boom and bust cycle. This will define the election outcome as a contrast between reversion to past mistakes versus Labour's forward plan for stability. During his campaign at Gateshead, he also mentioned supporting Blair's Iraq efforts and highlighted government reforms aimed at healthcare reform and youth unemployment reduction.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Chancellor Rallies Labour Voters (2005) by Gordon Brown is a railing cry warning the staaks too high for supporters, reminding them of the risky choice between Labour investments and Torie cuts. The chaoncellor issued a clear and fundamental choice between Labour's plans to invest in services and Torie's plan to plunge Britain into financial ruin. He argued that the Conservatives planned to return to mistakes of ERM, 10% inflation, $3bn lost reserve funds, £3bn interest rates, 250,000 reposseessed homes, one million unemployed and three million unfed, a central dividing line at the election between Labour taking Britain back and investing in services versus plunging Britain into financial ruin. The speech emphasized the economy's need for stability and growth in the third term of the Labour government, including continued affordable housing, £100bn debt relief, a national minimum wage, and child and youth poverty alleviation programs. The prime minister also promised to end teenage unequalities within five years, a network of children's centers, and flexibility in maternity leave policies.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced a rallying cry for the next general election, warning that Labour's rivals would be seen as having chosen the wrong side and would not be allowed to win. In his speech, he criticized the Conservatives for their record in government and claimed that Britain had lost "the money it needed" under their leadership. Brown argued for a "clear and fundamental choice" between Labour investment and Tory cuts, warning that voters faced higher taxes and means-testing under the Conservatives. The chancellor also criticized shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin for plotting cuts, likening it to the Tories' attempt to remove every teacher from the classroom and sack thousands of healthcare professionals. Brown accused Letwin of wanting Britain to return to "the mistakes of ERM and 10%" in government, comparing his record to that of Labour leader Tony Blair.
phi:2.7b: Chancellor Gordon Brown urged Labour voters at their conference in Gateshead to vote for Labour in the next general election due on 5 May. He warned of the high stakes and promised a clear choice between investment and Tory cuts. The Conservatives and Lib Dems accused Labour of higher taxes and means-testing under their policies. Mr Brown pledged to continue economic stability, fight child and pensioner poverty, and help young people get onto the property ladder. Shadow Chancellor George Osborne criticized the speech as repetitive and warned of higher taxes under Labour's plans. Liberal Democrat shadow chancellor Vince Cable noted that Gordon Brown's record was mixed and the country faced economic problems ahead. The prime minister also engaged with the public during the conference by answering questions sent in by e-mail, text message, and phone.
orca-mini:3b: Gordon Brown has warned Labour voters not to stay at home or protest vote in the next general election, saying the stakes are too high to let the Tories win. He accused shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin of plotting cuts that were the equivalent of sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in the country. The Labour Party must be "prepared to fight" and take Britain forward, he said, promising to continue economic stability and growth in a third term in power. He also pledged to continue the fight against child and pensioner poverty and create a network of children's centres.
hermes3:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown urges Labour supporters not to protest vote in general election, warning of 'too high stakes'. Cites investment vs Tory cuts as key dividing line. Pledges continued economic stability and growth in a third term, child poverty fight, young people property help and maternity leave flexibility.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Chancellor Gordon Brown urged Labour supporters to rally behind the party during a spring conference address, warning that the "stakes are too high" for voters to stay at home or protest vote in the upcoming general election. Brown promised economic stability and growth in a third term, continued efforts against child and pensioner poverty, and pledged assistance for first-time homebuyers and young people seeking employment. He also discussed plans for 100% debt relief for impoverished countries, a national minimum wage for 16 and 17-year-olds, and flexibility in maternity leave. In response, Conservative George Osborne criticized Brown's speech as more of the same rhetoric without details on filling the budget gap.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Gordon Brown urged Labour supporters to vote in the upcoming general election, warning that the choice was between Labour investment and Conservative cuts. Speaking at the party's spring conference, he criticized the Tories for planning £35bn in service cuts and promised continued economic stability, investment in public services, and initiatives to combat child and pensioner poverty. He also pledged support for first-time homebuyers, an end to teenage unemployment, and 100% debt relief for the world's poorest countries. His speech received criticism from Conservative and Liberal Democrat leaders, who accused him of failing to address tax increases and economic challenges. Meanwhile, Tony Blair defended the Iraq war and expressed his commitment to continuing as prime minister to implement further reforms.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chancellor rallies Labour voters against Conservative wins; promising economic stability, cutting poverty and unemployment. Gordon Brown warns about potential mistakes in past governments and promises a forward-looking Labour government focused on reforming hospitals, schools, and public services. The Conservatives insist they will lead to higher taxes and means-testing under Labour, while the Liberal Democrats criticize Gordon Brown's mixed record in terms of centralization and bureaucracy.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Gordon Brown, during Labour's spring conference at Gateshead's Sage Centre, urged supporters to vote in the upcoming general election, emphasizing a clear choice between Labour's investment and the Conservatives' cuts. He vowed to avoid past mistakes like ERM and high inflation, promising stability for public services and economic growth if Labour returns to power. Brown pledged £60bn more for hospitals, schools, and reforming other services by 2008, as well as ending teenage unemployment within five years. He announced plans for debt relief for poor countries, a national minimum wage for 16-17-year-olds, children's centres, and flexible maternity leave.

Conservative shadow chief secretary George Osborne criticized Brown's speech as more past focus than future plans, questioning the funding of Labour's spending promises. Liberal Democrat Vince Cable cautioned that while Brown's economic record was mixed, it included extensive centralization and complex taxation systems, raising concerns about potential future economic challenges, particularly high personal debt levels.

Prime Minister Tony Blair also participated in the event, taking questions from the public via email, text, and telephone. He defended his stance on the Iraq war, stating it could make Britain safer if successful, and expressed a desire to withdraw troops soon but not until the job was done. Blair also declared his intention to remain prime minister due to believed necessary changes for the country.
reference: Responding to the speech, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, George Osborne, said: "This was more talk from Gordon Brown."There will be a simple choice at the election - value for money and lower taxes with the Conservatives, or more waste and higher taxes under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown."The chancellor said the poll - expected to fall on 5 May - would give a "clear and fundamental" choice between Labour investment and Tory cuts.Laying into the Conservative's record in government he said: "I give you this promise - with Labour, Britain will never return to the mistakes of ERM and 10% inflation, 15% interest rates, £3bn in lost reserves, 250,000 repossessed, one million in negative equity and three million unemployed.Liberal Democrat shadow chancellor Vince Cable warned the picture was not as rosy as Mr Brown would like to portray it."For all his trumpeting of Labour's management of the economy, Gordon Brown's record is very mixed," he said.Gordon Brown has issued a rallying cry to supporters, warning the "stakes are too high" to stay at home or protest vote in the next general election.To a packed audience at Gateshead's Sage Centre, Mr Brown accused shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin of plotting cuts that were the equivalent of sacking every teacher, GP and nurse in the country.Mr Blair told the audience he believed the Iraq war would have made Britain a safer place if its emerging democracy succeeded and that he wanted to bring troops home as soon as possible, but not before the job was done.He also said he wanted to carry on as PM "because I still think that there are big changes our country needs"."For all his positive words, Gordon Brown is faced with economic problems looming on the horizon, not least the unprecedented levels of personal debt facing the nation."
